contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Use British English|date=April 2012}} [[File:Humphrey Hody.jpg|thumb|Humphrey Hody, line engraving by [[Michael Vandergucht]]]] '''Humphrey Hody''' (1659 – 20 January 1707) was an [[England|English]] scholar and [[theology|theologian]]. ==Life== He was born at [[Odcombe]] in [[Somerset]] in 1659.<ref>{{cite web|title=Humphrey Hody (1659–1706)|url=http://words.fromoldbooks.org/Chalmers-Biography/h/hody-humphrey.html|publisher=Chalmers|accessdate=26 August 2012}}</ref> In 1676 he entered [[Wadham College, Oxford]], of which he became a fellow in 1685. In 1692 he became chaplain to [[Edward Stillingfleet]], [[bishop of Worcester]], and for his support of the ruling party in a controversy with [[Henry Dodwell]] regarding the non-juring bishops he was appointed chaplain to Archbishop [[John Tillotson]], an office which he continued to hold under [[Thomas Tenison]]. In 1698 he was appointed regius professor of [[Greek language|Greek]] at Oxford, and in 1704 was made [[archdeacon]] of Oxford. ==Works== In 1684 he published ''Contra historiam Aristeae de LXX. interpretibus dissertatio'', in which he argued that the so-called "letter of [[Aristeas]]", containing an account of the production of the [[Septuagint]], was the late forgery of a [[Ancient Greece|Hellenic]] [[Jew]] originally circulated to lend authority to that version. The dissertation was generally regarded as conclusive, although [[Isaac Vossius]] published an angry and scurrilous reply to it in the appendix to his edition of ''[[Pomponius Mela]]''.<ref>{{cite book| last = Champion| first = J.A.I| title = The Pillars of Priestcraft Shaken: The Church of England and its Enemies, 1660-1730| url = http://books.google.com/?id=m5BOAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA50| year = 1992| publisher = Cambridge Studies in Early Modern British History| isbn = 978-0521405362| pages = 48-52 }}</ref> In 1689 Hody wrote the ''Prolegomena to the Greek chronicle of [[John Malalas]]'', published at Oxford in 1691. In 1701 he published ''A History of English Councils and Convocations'',<ref>{{cite book| last = Hody| first = Humphrey| title = A History of English Concils and Convocations| url = http://books.google.com/?id=IopNpwAACAAJ| year = 2011| publisher = BiblioBazaar| isbn = 978-1-173-57826-8 }}</ref> and in 1703 in four volumes ''De Bibliorum textis originalibus'',<ref>{{cite book| last = Hody| first = Humphrey| title = De bibliorum textibus originalibus, versionibus graecis, et latina Vulgata| url = http://books.google.com/?id=BSlEAAAAcAAJ| year = 1705| publisher = Thef. Scheldoniano }}</ref> in which he included a revision of his work on the Septuagint,<ref>{{cite web|title=Humphrey Hody|url=http://gluedideas.com/content-collection/cyclopedia-of-biblical-literature/Humphrey-Hody.html|publisher=Glued Ideas|accessdate=26 August 2012}}</ref> and published a reply to Vossius. A work, ''De Graecis Illustribus'', which he left in manuscript, was published in 1742 by [[Samuel Jebb]], who prefixed to it a Latin life of the author. ==References== {{reflist}} * {{1911}} {{Authority control|VIAF=64350268}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Hody, Humphrey | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION =Theologian | DATE OF BIRTH = 1659 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 20 January 1707 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hody, Humphrey}} [[Category:1659 births]] [[Category:1707 deaths]] [[Category:People from South Somerset (district)]] [[Category:English theologians]] [[Category:Alumni of Wadham College, Oxford]]
